items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.81mAOD at 06:45 on 24/08/24 and 4.70mAOD at 18:45 on 24/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 19 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 24/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from Storm Lilian has now reduced.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Friday 23rd August. High water at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is at 21:45 BST. Times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 5 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be around 210mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it;
The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is 5.09 mAOD, this is 0.21 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this evening.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued because of recent high tides that peaked yesterday evening Thursday 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks.
Newport 7.1m to 7.4m at 22:45 on 23/08/2024. Avonmouth Portbury 7.4 to 7.7m at 22:45 on 23/08/2024.
No thresholds are expected to be crossed on Saturday mornings tide as predicted Spring peaks are now falling.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 2pm on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides and  strong winds overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 02:55 AM on 24/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss.
The flood gates at St. Georges Quay, Lancaster remain closed.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
The flood alert has now been removed and no further high tides are currently forecast. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. No flooding is expected.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024.  
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 03:45 AM on 24/08/2024 at the following locations:  
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 03:45 AM,
Eastford Road, peaking around 04:00 AM,
Arpley Bridge, peaking around 04:15 AM,
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
Following tomorrow morning, no further tidal impacts are expected. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.  
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 24/08/2024, by 12:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the possibility of spray overtopping on the coast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 24/08/2024. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 02:45 AM 24/08/2024. Flooding of property is not expected.
Following tomorrow morning, no further overtopping is currently being forecast.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 24/08/2024 by 12:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood Alert has been issued due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast from tomorrow, Saturday 24/08/2024 and over the coming days. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 8.15am and 11am tomorrow, Saturday 24/08/2024 and again between 9.30am and 12.30pm on Sunday, 25/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9.00am on Saturday 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.53 mAODN at 11:00 PM on 23/08/2024, with south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation and closing flood gates.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 02:55 AM on 24/08/2024. Flooding is possible 3 hours either side of this time.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Saturday's early morning tide at 03:00 on 24/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with light Southerly Force 2 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 6.08 metres Chart Datum (3.03 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:45 on 24/08/2024 is forecast to be the same height (3.03 mAOD). Similar minor flood impacts are predicted again at each high tide‚ but should reduce from Sunday (25/08/2024). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Take care if visiting Climping beach. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 24/08/2024.

items.description: Coast at Barrow in Furness

Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include the coastline at Barrow in Furness. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. After tonight’s high tide coastal conditions are expected to improve and we do not expect to issue this Flood Alert again for subsequent tides. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 03:15 and 05:15, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.4mAODN at 04:15, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.24m above tide tables, wind Force 3, in a southerly direction. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 09:00 tomorrow morning, Saturday 24 August.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.
 
This alert is in force for the this evenings high tide, Thursday (22/08/2024) Friday mornings tide (23/08/2024), and Saturday mornings tide (24/08/24). 
High tides are anticipated between 17:30 and 19:30, 22/08/2024, 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 and 06:00 and 08:00 24/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 02:45 and 04:45, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.75mAODN at 03:45, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind Force 4, in a south westerly direction. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 09:00 tomorrow morning, Saturday 24 August.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: High tides, strong winds and large waves overnight may lead to flooding. The highest tide level at North Morecambe Bay is expected at 2:45 AM on 24/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. After tonight’s high tide coastal conditions are expected to improve and we do not expect to issue this Flood Alert again for subsequent tides. We have closed the flood gates at Arnside promenade but expect to re-open them on Saturday 24/08/2024. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible at low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths. Property flooding is not expected.
The high tide water level is expected at 4:15 AM on 24/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Flooding at low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths is also possible tomorrow afternoon at 4:45 PM on 24/08/2024. 
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Sheerness. The first forecast high tide water level is 3.45 mAODN at 4:15 AM on 24/08/2024, which is 0.43 m above tide tables, with south-westerly force 4 winds. The second forecast high tide water level is 3.45 mAODN at 4:45 PM on 24/08/2024, which is 0.4 m above tide tables, with south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.47mAOD at 04:45 on 24/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 19 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 24/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to remain high and cause flooding to low lying land and roads. The forecast is now improving meaning levels with fall throughout today 23/08/2024.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. items.description: Lower River Eden
items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding of low lying land and roads. Flooding is possible from 2:00 PM on 23/08/2024 and levels are expected to be at their highest at around 5:00PM.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the morning and over the weekend.  More rain is forecast for Sunday evening 25/8/24 into Monday morning 26/8/24.

Areas most at risk include River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Wampool and Ellen
Keswick Campsite
items.message:
Due to overnight rain lake levels are expected to remain high, causing flooding in the area.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site  .

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with campsite staff.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Cole as a result of localised thunderstorms. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible on 24/08/2024 in the morning. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to rise until the afternoon on24/08/2024. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow afternoon, 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. There are rainfall showers forecast over the weekend, but we do not anticipate issuing further flood alerts at this time. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tyne estuary at Newcastle Quayside, Low Walker, Lower Derwenthaugh Industrial Estate and Willington

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the Tyne Estuary for the Saturday morning tide, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow’s high tide. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
River levels are now falling below flood risk thresholds and there is no longer a threat of flooding, as Storm Lilian passes. Standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this evening or throughout the weekend.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Rivers Caldew and Petteril
Rivers Esk and Irthing
items.message:
Heavy rainfall in the early hours have caused rising river levels, which may lead to flooding of land and road.  Flooding is possible from 6:00 AM on 23/08/2024.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the morning and no  flood warnings are expected.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00am 24/8/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this evening.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river and lake levels in the area to remain high and cause flooding to low lying land and roads. The forecast is now improving meaning levels with fall throughout today 23/08/2024.

Areas most at risk include Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
